data_findings.finding: Key algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing: 1) No-fit polygon (NFP) for O(1) overlap checks, 2) Bottom-left heuristic for constructive placement, 3) Simulated annealing/genetic algorithms for optimization, 4) Jostle algorithm for local search, 5) Extended local search with nonlinear programming. The problem is NP-hard.

Competition uses pre-compiled C++ binaries (bbox3, shake_public, tree_packer) for optimization. The tree shape is a 15-vertex polygon with specific dimensions. Score = sum(side^2/n) for n=1 to 200. Key techniques: simulated annealing, local search, squeeze/compaction, rotation optimization, backward propagation (removing trees from larger N to improve smaller N).

No-fit polygon (NFP) is a key technique for 2D polygon packing. It represents all positions where two polygons touch or overlap, enabling O(k) overlap detection instead of O(nm). Can be computed using Minkowski sums. Essential for efficient packing algorithms.

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding:
Para resolver problemas de optimización de empaquetamiento de polígonos irregulares en 2D, existen varias clases de algoritmos que han demostrado ser efectivos. Entre los enfoques más destacados están los algoritmos heurísticos y metaheurísticos, que buscan soluciones cercanas a óptimas en tiempos razonables. Por ejemplo, la revisión de Petrillo et al. (2022) señala que en estos problemas se utilizan algoritmos heurísticos, metaheurísticos y algoritmos exactos, adaptados a las características específicas de los polígonos irregulares ([frontiers](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmech.2022.966691/full)). 

En particular, el uso de algoritmos genéticos combinados con programación lineal ha sido explorado para optimizar el empaquetamiento irregular en 2D, logrando soluciones eficientes sin restringir la orientación de las piezas, lo cual aumenta la flexibilidad del proceso ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474)). Además, enfoques basados en algoritmos de búsqueda

web_research.query: What is the no-fit polygon (NFP) technique for 2D polygon packing and how does it work?
web_research.finding:
The no-fit polygon (NFP) technique is a geometric method used in 2D polygon packing problems, particularly for irregular shapes. It involves calculating a set of feasible positions where one polygon can be placed relative to another without overlapping. The NFP essentially represents the boundary of all positions where the polygons would touch or intersect if placed in any configuration, thus helping to identify valid placements efficiently ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0305054806000669), [ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221706001639)).

The core of the NFP technique often involves the use of Minkowski sums, a mathematical operation that combines two shapes to produce a new shape representing all possible translations of one shape around the other. By computing the Minkowski sum of the two polygons, the NFP can be derived, which delineates the boundary of all positions where the polygons are just touchi
